claim: If A is older than B, and B is older than C, then A is older than C

supporting.text: This is a direct application of the transitive property of inequality, which is a fundamental mathematical principle.

attacks.text: This is a direct application of the transitive property of inequality, which is a fundamental mathematical principle.
The transitive property may not hold in all contexts, such as subjective comparisons like 'preference' or 'beauty'.
In real-world scenarios, measurement errors or incomplete data can invalidate the transitive assumption.
Mathematical principles are abstract and may not perfectly map to real-world age comparisons due to factors like time zones or relativistic effects.
Even in subjective contexts, the transitive property often holds as a useful approximation.
Measurement errors can be mitigated through statistical methods, preserving the validity of the transitive property.
Incomplete data can be addressed by explicitly modeling uncertainty rather than rejecting transitivity.

supporting.text: In any ordered set where 'older than' is a transitive relation, the conclusion logically follows from the premises.

attacks.text: In any ordered set where 'older than' is a transitive relation, the conclusion logically follows from the premises.
Transitivity does not always hold in real-world scenarios due to exceptions like time dilation in relativity.
Human age perception can be subjective, making the 'older than' relation non-transitive in practice.
Time dilation effects are negligible at human scales, so transitivity holds for practical purposes.
Legal and biological definitions of age provide objective criteria, ensuring transitivity.

supporting.text: Empirical observations in age comparisons consistently support the transitive nature of the 'older than' relation.

attacks.text: Empirical observations in age comparisons consistently support the transitive nature of the 'older than' relation.
Some empirical studies have shown exceptions in age comparisons due to errors in data collection or reporting.
Cultural differences in age reporting can lead to inconsistencies, undermining the universality of the transitive relation.
Standardized age verification methods minimize errors, ensuring reliable transitive conclusions.
Globalization has reduced cultural discrepancies in age reporting, making the transitive relation more reliable.
Even with standardized methods, human error in data entry can still occur, affecting reliability.
Some cultures resist global standards, maintaining discrepancies in age reporting.

supporting.text: If A is older than B, and B is older than C, then by definition, A must have existed before C, making A older than C.

attacks.text: If A is older than B, and B is older than C, then by definition, A must have existed before C, making A older than C.
The definition of 'older than' may not always be transitive in contexts like biological aging or relativistic time dilation.
In classical logic and most real-world contexts, 'older than' is strictly transitive, so the original argument holds.
If A, B, and C are not part of the same timeline (e.g., in parallel universes), the transitivity of 'older than' breaks down.
The claim implicitly assumes a shared timeline, making parallel universe scenarios irrelevant to its validity.

supporting.text: All formal systems that model age or time dependencies treat the 'older than' relation as transitive, reinforcing the claim's validity.

attacks.text: All formal systems that model age or time dependencies treat the 'older than' relation as transitive, reinforcing the claim's validity.
Some informal or non-mathematical contexts may not strictly adhere to transitivity in age comparisons.
Formal systems are designed to model idealized scenarios, which may not always align with real-world interpretations.
There exist alternative logical frameworks where transitivity is not assumed for age relations.
Standard formal systems are widely accepted and validated, making deviations from them statistically insignificant.
